title: Judges Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 3.

questions.question: According to Judges 3:1, why did the LORD leave certain nations among Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: To prove Israel by them
questions.explanation: Judges 3:1 states that the nations were left by the LORD to prove Israel by them.

questions.question: Which groups of people did the children of Israel live among, according to Judges 3:5?
options: Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites
questions.correctAnswer: Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites
questions.explanation: Judges 3:5 lists these specific groups among whom the children of Israel dwelt.

questions.question: What did the children of Israel do that was evil in the sight of the LORD, as described in Judges 3:7?
options: They forgot the LORD and served Baalim and the groves
They built idols of gold and silver
They refused to fight their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They forgot the LORD and served Baalim and the groves
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7 clearly states the children of Israel forgot the LORD and served Baalim and the groves.

questions.question: Who was the king of Mesopotamia that ruled over Israel for eight years, according to Judges 3:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Chushanrishathaim
questions.explanation: Judges 3:8 says the LORD sold Israel into the hand of Chushanrishathaim king of Mesopotamia.

questions.question: Who was raised up by the LORD to deliver Israel from the king of Mesopotamia, as stated in Judges 3:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Othniel, son of Kenaz
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9 tells that the LORD raised up Othniel son of Kenaz to deliver Israel.

questions.question: How long did the land have rest after Othniel judged Israel, according to Judges 3:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Judges 3:11 states the land had rest for forty years after Othniel's leadership.

questions.question: Which king did the LORD strengthen against Israel because they did evil again, as described in Judges 3:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Eglon, king of Moab
questions.explanation: Judges 3:12 says the LORD strengthened Eglon king of Moab against Israel.

questions.question: For how many years did the children of Israel serve Eglon, king of Moab, according to Judges 3:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Eighteen years
questions.explanation: Judges 3:14 states that Israel served Eglon for eighteen years.

questions.question: What was unique about Ehud, the deliverer raised by the LORD, mentioned in Judges 3:15?
questions.correctAnswer: He was left-handed
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15 describes Ehud as a man who was lefthanded.

questions.question: What kind of weapon did Ehud make for himself, as described in Judges 3:16?
options: A double-edged dagger a cubit long
A spear with a sharp point
questions.correctAnswer: A double-edged dagger a cubit long
questions.explanation: Judges 3:16 says Ehud made a dagger with two edges, a cubit in length.

questions.question: Where was Eglon sitting when Ehud approached him with a message from God, according to Judges 3:20?
options: In a tent outside the city
questions.correctAnswer: In a summer parlour
questions.explanation: Judges 3:20 says Eglon was sitting in a summer parlour when Ehud came to him.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 3:23 states that Ehud locked the doors of the parlour after killing Eglon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 3:23 confirms Ehud shut and locked the parlour doors after killing Eglon.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 3:27, Ehud blew a trumpet to gather the children of Israel after killing Eglon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 3:27 records that Ehud blew a trumpet in the mountain of Ephraim to gather Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 3:31 says Shamgar slew six hundred men of the Philistines with a sword.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 3:31 states Shamgar killed six hundred Philistines with an ox goad, not a sword.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Judges 3:29: 'And they slew of Moab at that time about ten thousand men, all lusty, and all men of ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: valour
questions.explanation: Judges 3:29 uses the word 'valour' to describe the men slain.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by their spiritual battles. Based on Judges 3, what biblical truth about trusting God in trials would you share?
options: God raises deliverers when His people cry out to Him
God leaves us to face all battles alone
Victory depends solely on our strength and wisdom
We must fight without asking for God's help
questions.correctAnswer: God raises deliverers when His people cry out to Him
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9-10 and 15 show that when Israel cried to the LORD, He raised deliverers like Othniel and Ehud to save them, teaching us to trust God and seek His help in trials.

questions.question: How does Judges 3 teach us about obedience and its consequences in family and community life?
options: Disobedience leads to oppression and suffering
Obedience has no real impact on family life
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to oppression and suffering
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 and 12-14 demonstrate that Israel's disobedience by serving other gods led to oppression by enemies, showing the importance of obedience for family and community well-being.

questions.question: A believer struggles with temptation to follow worldly influences. How does Judges 3 guide us about resisting such temptations?
options: Serving other gods leads to spiritual and physical defeat
It is acceptable to mix worship practices
Idolatry is a minor issue God overlooks
questions.correctAnswer: Serving other gods leads to spiritual and physical defeat
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7 and 12 teach that Israel's serving Baalim and other gods brought God's anger and defeat, warning us to resist idolatry and stay faithful to God.

questions.question: What does Judges 3 reveal about the role of prayer and personal devotion in overcoming difficulties?
options: Crying out to the LORD leads to divine intervention and deliverance
Prayer is unnecessary when facing enemies
Personal devotion has no effect on national crises
questions.correctAnswer: Crying out to the LORD leads to divine intervention and deliverance
questions.explanation: In verses 9 and 15, Israel's cries to God prompt Him to raise deliverers, underscoring the power of prayer and devotion in overcoming challenges.

questions.question: How does the example of Ehud in Judges 3 encourage humility and reliance on God's wisdom rather than human strength?
options: Ehud used his unique skills and God's guidance to deliver Israel
Ehud relied solely on physical strength to defeat the enemy
Pride and arrogance led Ehud to success
Ehud sought help only from military allies
questions.correctAnswer: Ehud used his unique skills and God's guidance to deliver Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15-27 shows Ehud, though left-handed and unexpected, used God's guidance and his skills to deliver Israel, teaching reliance on God's wisdom rather than human pride.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by repeated failures. Based on Judges 3, what biblical principle about perseverance through trials can you share?
options: God allows cycles of testing and delivers repeatedly when we repent
Once we fail, God abandons us permanently
We must rely only on our own strength to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: God allows cycles of testing and delivers repeatedly when we repent
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7-8, 12-15 show Israel repeatedly fell into sin but God delivered them when they cried out and repented, encouraging perseverance and trust in God's mercy.

questions.question: What does Judges 3 teach about the importance of spiritual discipline and obedience in parenting and family life?
options: Marrying outside faith and serving other gods leads to forgetting God
Family choices do not affect spiritual health
Discipline is unnecessary in faith development
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying outside faith and serving other gods leads to forgetting God
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 describe Israel marrying Canaanite women and serving their gods, leading to forgetting the LORD, emphasizing the need for godly discipline in families.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 3 shows that God tests His people through difficult circumstances to teach them obedience and reliance on Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 3:1-4 explains that God left certain nations to prove Israel and teach them war and obedience, showing testing serves to teach reliance on God.

questions.question: True or False: The story of Shamgar in Judges 3 emphasizes that God can use unexpected people and means to accomplish His purposes.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 3:31 tells of Shamgar, who delivered Israel by killing 600 Philistines with an ox goad, illustrating God's power through unlikely instruments.

questions.question: In Judges 3, Israel's repeated turning to other gods illustrates a warning about which biblical virtue?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7 demonstrates Israel's evil by forsaking the LORD and serving Baalim, highlighting the necessity of faithfulness to God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive and reconcile after being hurt. How does Judges 3 reflect God's attitude toward restoration after failure?
options: God repeatedly provides deliverance upon repentance
God permanently rejects those who sin
Restoration depends on human efforts alone
Forgiveness is only for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God repeatedly provides deliverance upon repentance
questions.explanation: Throughout Judges 3 (verses 9-10, 15-30), God delivers Israel repeatedly after they repent, showing His readiness to restore and forgive.

questions.question: How does the example of Othniel in Judges 3 teach us about humility and serving others within the church community?
options: Othniel was raised quietly and served as judge to bring peace
Othniel sought personal glory over service
Leadership is only for the most powerful
Judging Israel was a position of honor for self-exaltation
questions.correctAnswer: Othniel was raised quietly and served as judge to bring peace
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9-11 shows Othniel, Caleb's younger brother, humbly judged and delivered Israel, teaching servant leadership and humility.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ehud, the deliverer raised by God, was a _______ man, which was key to his success in Judges 3.
questions.correctAnswer: lefthanded
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15 states Ehud was a lefthanded man, which enabled him to conceal his weapon and successfully deliver Israel.

questions.question: What does Judges 3 teach about integrity and honesty in daily life through the actions of Israel's deliverers?
options: They acted with courage and trust in God rather than deceit for personal gain
They used trickery for selfish purposes
Delivers relied on lies to win battles
Integrity was less important than success
questions.correctAnswer: They acted with courage and trust in God rather than deceit for personal gain
questions.explanation: Othniel and Ehud acted with courage and faith in God's power (Judges 3:9-10, 15-26), showing integrity and dependence on God rather than selfish trickery.

questions.question: Based on Judges 3, how should a believer respond when facing spiritual complacency in their life or church?
options: Cry out to the LORD and seek His deliverance
Ignore the problem and hope it resolves
Rely only on human solutions without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to the LORD and seek His deliverance
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9 and 15 show that when Israel repented and cried to God, He delivered them, teaching believers to seek God in times of spiritual decline.

questions.question: How does Judges 3 illustrate the importance of stewardship and responsibility in spiritual warfare and life challenges?
options: Israel was tested and learned war to be responsible stewards of their land
Spiritual warfare is not the believer's responsibility
Success does not require preparation or learning
God does all the work without human participation
questions.correctAnswer: Israel was tested and learned war to be responsible stewards of their land
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 explain God left nations to test Israel and teach them war, emphasizing our responsibility to prepare and steward what God entrusts to us.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 3.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of the LORD leaving certain nations among the Israelites according to Judges 3?
options: To prove Israel and teach them war
To punish Israel for their disobedience
To give Israel land for farming
To encourage Israel to form alliances
questions.correctAnswer: To prove Israel and teach them war
questions.explanation: Judges 3:1-2 explain that the LORD left these nations to prove Israel and teach the generations who had not known war about warfare.

questions.question: Which groups of people dwelt in the land to test Israel as mentioned in Judges 3?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines, Canaanites, Sidonians, and Hivites
questions.explanation: Judges 3:3 lists the nations including five lords of the Philistines, Canaanites, Sidonians, and Hivites as those left to test Israel.

questions.question: What sin did the children of Israel commit that led to God's anger and their oppression?
options: They served Baalim and the groves, forsaking the LORD
They refused to fight in battles
They worshiped the God of Egypt
They destroyed the altar of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: They served Baalim and the groves, forsaking the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7 states Israel did evil by forgetting the LORD and serving Baalim and the groves, which provoked God's anger.

questions.question: Who was the first deliverer raised by the LORD to save Israel from Mesopotamian oppression?
questions.correctAnswer: Othniel, son of Kenaz
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9 identifies Othniel as the deliverer raised by the LORD to rescue Israel from Chushanrishathaim.

questions.question: What special characteristic of Ehud is highlighted that played a role in his deliverance mission?
questions.correctAnswer: He was left-handed
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15 specifically notes Ehud was left-handed, which is significant for his secretive approach to kill King Eglon.

questions.question: Where did Ehud conceal his two-edged dagger when approaching King Eglon?
options: Under his raiment on his right thigh
Under his cloak on his left side
questions.correctAnswer: Under his raiment on his right thigh
questions.explanation: Judges 3:16 states Ehud girded the two-edged dagger under his clothing on his right thigh, allowing a surprise attack.

questions.question: What literary technique is evident in the description of Ehud’s assassination of Eglon with the dagger and the fat closing upon the blade?
options: Vivid imagery illustrating the lethality and finality of the act
Chiasm highlighting the reversal of power
questions.correctAnswer: Vivid imagery illustrating the lethality and finality of the act
questions.explanation: Judges 3:22 uses vivid imagery to describe the dagger stuck in Eglon’s belly, symbolizing the irreversible nature of the act.

questions.question: How long did the land have rest after Othniel judged Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Judges 3:11 records that after Othniel’s deliverance, the land had rest for forty years.

questions.question: Which nations allied with Eglon, king of Moab, to oppress Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Children of Ammon and Amalek
questions.explanation: Judges 3:13 states that Eglon gathered Ammonites and Amalekites to attack Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ehud blowing a trumpet in the mountain of Ephraim after killing Eglon?
options: It signaled the Israelites to mobilize and attack Moab
It was a call for a religious assembly
It was a warning to neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: It signaled the Israelites to mobilize and attack Moab
questions.explanation: Judges 3:27-28 describes Ehud blowing the trumpet to summon Israel to pursue and defeat the Moabites.

questions.question: How many men of valour were slain by Israel in the battle against Moab during Ehud’s leadership?
questions.correctAnswer: About ten thousand
questions.explanation: Judges 3:29 reports that Israel killed about ten thousand men of valour during the Moabite defeat.

questions.question: What weapon did Shamgar use to deliver Israel from the Philistines?
questions.correctAnswer: An ox goad
questions.explanation: Judges 3:31 says Shamgar slew six hundred Philistines with an ox goad, a farming tool repurposed as a weapon.

questions.question: True or False: The repeated cycles of sin and deliverance in Judges 3 foreshadow the later kingship struggles in Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The cyclical pattern of sin, oppression, crying out, and deliverance in Judges 3 (e.g., 3:7-11, 3:12-30) is a literary and theological motif that anticipates Israel’s later struggles under kingship.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the Spirit of the LORD coming upon Othniel in Judges 3:10?
options: It signifies divine empowerment for leadership and victory
It marks Othniel as a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies divine empowerment for leadership and victory
questions.explanation: Judges 3:10 shows that the Spirit of the LORD enabled Othniel to judge Israel and prevail in battle, underscoring God’s role in deliverance.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Ehud’s assassination of Eglon reflect ancient Near Eastern cultural practices of diplomacy and warfare?
options: The use of a secret message and a gift to gain access reflects diplomatic customs
It shows the importance of public trials before execution
It emphasizes the role of chariots in battle
It demonstrates the use of siege warfare tactics
questions.correctAnswer: The use of a secret message and a gift to gain access reflects diplomatic customs
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15-19 portrays Ehud delivering a gift and claiming a secret message, a tactic consistent with ancient Near Eastern diplomatic protocols to approach rulers.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose for God leaving certain nations in the land according to Judges 3:1-4?
options: To prove Israel and teach them warfare
To allow Israel to intermarry with foreigners
To provide Israel with trade partners
questions.correctAnswer: To prove Israel and teach them warfare
questions.explanation: Judges 3:1-4 clearly states that God left these nations to test Israel and to teach those who had not known war, fitting into God's sovereign plan to train and test His people. This doctrine is consistent with Deuteronomy 8:2 where God tests Israel in the wilderness, Romans 5:3-4 where suffering produces perseverance, and Hebrews 12:7 which speaks of God disciplining His children.

questions.question: According to Judges 3:6-7, what was Israel's response to dwelling among the Canaanites and other nations?
options: They took foreign wives and served their gods
They drove out the Canaanites completely
They kept separate and worshiped only the LORD
They made alliances but kept their faith pure
questions.correctAnswer: They took foreign wives and served their gods
questions.explanation: Judges 3:6-7 explains Israel's sin of intermarriage and idolatry, which led them to forsake the LORD. This reflects humanity's tendency toward sin and idolatry (Romans 1:21-23), the danger of spiritual compromise (2 Corinthians 6:14-16), and God's call to holiness (1 Peter 1:15-16).

questions.question: Who was the first deliverer God raised up to rescue Israel from Mesopotamian oppression?
questions.correctAnswer: Othniel, son of Kenaz
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9-10 identifies Othniel as the deliverer raised by God to save Israel from Chushanrishathaim. This demonstrates God's mercy and sovereignty in salvation (Exodus 3:7-8), typifying Christ as the ultimate deliverer (Galatians 4:4-5), and the Spirit empowering judges (Judges 3:10 parallels Acts 10:38).

questions.question: How long did the land have rest after Othniel's deliverance?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Judges 3:11 states the land had rest for forty years after Othniel's judgeship, illustrating God's blessing and peace following repentance and deliverance. This echoes the biblical theme of rest as a blessing from God (Psalm 37:11, Hebrews 4:9-10), and the covenantal pattern of blessing and discipline (Leviticus 26:3-6).

questions.question: What was the consequence of Israel doing evil again according to Judges 3:12-14?
options: God strengthened Eglon, king of Moab, to oppress Israel
Israel was given a new land
The LORD sent rain and harvest
Israel built a temple for Baal
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthened Eglon, king of Moab, to oppress Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 3:12-14 shows God's righteous judgment in response to Israel's sin, by empowering their enemies against them. This reflects the holiness of God and His justice (Nahum 1:3), the principle of sowing and reaping (Galatians 6:7), and the call to repentance (2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: Who was the left-handed deliverer that God raised up to deliver Israel from Moabite oppression?
questions.correctAnswer: Ehud, son of Gera
questions.explanation: Judges 3:15 introduces Ehud, a left-handed Benjamite, as the deliverer God raised up in response to Israel's cry. This exemplifies God's use of unexpected means and people for salvation (1 Corinthians 1:27-29), and the sovereignty of God in election and deliverance (Romans 9:15-16).

questions.question: What unique weapon did Ehud prepare to assassinate King Eglon according to Judges 3:16?
options: A double-edged dagger of a cubit length
A spear with a golden tip
A sword with a jeweled hilt
questions.correctAnswer: A double-edged dagger of a cubit length
questions.explanation: Judges 3:16 describes Ehud's two-edged dagger, which he concealed to carry out God's deliverance plan. This highlights themes of divine providence and God’s use of human instruments (Exodus 14:14), foreshadowing Christ’s double-edged sword as the Word of God (Hebrews 4:12).

questions.question: How did Ehud gain access to King Eglon before killing him, as described in Judges 3:19-20?
options: By claiming he had a secret message from God
By disguising himself as a Moabite soldier
By sneaking through a hidden passage
questions.correctAnswer: By claiming he had a secret message from God
questions.explanation: Judges 3:19-20 recounts Ehud telling Eglon he had a secret message from God, which led to private access. This emphasizes the theme of God’s word and messenger being powerful and effective (Isaiah 55:11), and God's mysterious methods of salvation (1 Corinthians 1:27).

questions.question: What was the immediate result after Ehud killed King Eglon according to Judges 3:23-25?
options: Ehud escaped while the servants delayed
questions.correctAnswer: Ehud escaped while the servants delayed
questions.explanation: Judges 3:23-25 shows that after killing Eglon, Ehud locked the doors and escaped while the servants delayed, illustrating God's timing and protection in deliverance (Psalm 34:7), and the believer’s call to trust God's providence (Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What did Ehud do to rally the Israelites after escaping from Moabite territory, as told in Judges 3:27-28?
options: He blew a trumpet to summon Israel to battle
He sent messengers to other tribes for help
He hid in the mountains waiting for reinforcements
He prayed alone in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: He blew a trumpet to summon Israel to battle
questions.explanation: Judges 3:27-28 explains that Ehud blew a trumpet on Mount Ephraim to call Israel to pursue the Moabites, demonstrating leadership empowered by God and the importance of united action in God's deliverance (Psalm 47:5, Nehemiah 4:20).

questions.question: How many men of Moab were slain by Israel during Ehud’s campaign according to Judges 3:29?
questions.correctAnswer: About ten thousand men
questions.explanation: Judges 3:29 records about ten thousand Moabite men slain, indicating a decisive victory granted by God. This reflects God's power in delivering His people (Psalm 18:39), and the defeat of enemies as a sign of God's covenant faithfulness (Exodus 15:3-4).

questions.question: How long did the land have rest after the Moabite defeat under Ehud's leadership according to Judges 3:30?
questions.correctAnswer: Eighty years
questions.explanation: Judges 3:30 states the land had rest for fourscore (eighty) years after Ehud's deliverance, showing God's blessing following obedience and repentance (Psalm 85:6), and prefiguring the ultimate rest found in Christ (Hebrews 4:9-10).

questions.question: Who succeeded Ehud as a deliverer and what notable feat did he accomplish according to Judges 3:31?
options: Shamgar, who killed six hundred Philistines with an ox goad
Gideon, who defeated the Midianites with 300 men
Jephthah, who delivered Israel from the Ammonites
Samson, who destroyed the Philistine temple
questions.correctAnswer: Shamgar, who killed six hundred Philistines with an ox goad
questions.explanation: Judges 3:31 describes Shamgar's deliverance by killing six hundred Philistines with an ox goad, illustrating God using unlikely instruments to accomplish salvation (1 Corinthians 1:27), and the theme of God’s power through weakness (2 Corinthians 12:9).

questions.question: What spiritual condition led to Israel's repeated oppression in Judges 3:7-8 and 12-14?
options: They did evil and forgot the LORD, serving Baalim and other gods
They were disobedient because of foreign alliances
They suffered due to natural disasters
They were deceived by false prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They did evil and forgot the LORD, serving Baalim and other gods
questions.explanation: Judges 3:7-8 and 12-14 reveal Israel's sin of idolatry and forgetting God as the root cause of divine judgment, consistent with the biblical doctrine that sin separates from God (Isaiah 59:2), and that repentance restores fellowship (1 John 1:9).

questions.question: What attribute of God is demonstrated by raising up judges like Othniel and Ehud in response to Israel's cries?
options: God’s mercy and faithfulness to deliver
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy and faithfulness to deliver
questions.explanation: Judges 3:9-10 and 3:15 show God's compassionate response to Israel's repentance by raising deliverers, reflecting His mercy (Exodus 34:6-7), faithfulness (Lamentations 3:22-23), and covenant love (Deuteronomy 7:9).

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by the cyclical pattern of sin, oppression, crying out, and deliverance in Judges 3?
options: God’s justice and redemption in covenant relationship
The finality of divine punishment without hope
The autonomy of human will without divine intervention
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice and redemption in covenant relationship
questions.explanation: The cycle in Judges 3 highlights God's just discipline and redeeming grace within His covenant, aligning with Romans 11:22 on God’s kindness and severity, 2 Chronicles 7:14 on repentance and restoration, and Hebrews 12 on God’s discipline as a loving Father.
